item.title: Moving Day
item.dc:creator: tdumont
item.description: This site has been moved. Please update your links; the URL is: http://tomsastroblog.com Click Here to go to the new site

item.title: I’m Back….again
item.dc:creator: tdumont
item.description: It was a long and unexpected hiatus from the blog. As quite a few of you know this isn’t the first occurrence in recent times and neither was my fault. Having a site go down every now and then is one thing but this is just silly. The worst part of [...]

item.title: Copernicus Found?
item.dc:creator: tdumont
item.description:
A team of Polish archaeologists think they may have discovered the remains of Copernicus (1473 to 1543) buried beneath an alter in Frombork cathedral.
Copernicus you may remember was an: astronomer, mathematician, and economist; he is credited with the theory that the planets rotated around the sun in his paper: On the Revolutions of the Heavenly [...]

item.title: Maxwell Montes
item.dc:creator: tdumont
item.description:
The launch of the Venus Express is not far away, all contamination has been removed and launch is scheduled for Wednesday, November 9th at 03:30 GMT.
I was over poking around Megan’s Blog, and she had a line to the Alder Planetarium and their interactive map of Venus. It’s quite good and you should pay a [...]

item.title: Dust Storm
item.dc:creator: tdumont
item.description:
Here’s a Hubble image of Mars taken on October 28 within a day of its closest approach to Earth.
Aside from being a stunning image, if you look at the center of the planet you will see a dust storm. The storm is huge, about the size of Texas, Oklahoma, and New Mexico combined! [...]

item.title: Tethys and Dione
item.dc:creator: tdumont
item.description:
Cassini imaged the two moons Tethys (foreground) and Dione shown here, on September 16th.
The moons are almost the same size; Tethys 665 miles (1,071 km) and Dione 700 miles (1,126 km) in diameter. The differences in the moons are quite apparent. Apart from the surface brightness, the fractures on Dione are contrasted by [...]

item.title: Westerlund 1
item.dc:creator: tdumont
item.description: The image in the left panel is an optical image of Westerlund 1. As you can see it is a cluster of stars, these stars are young and several have masses of about 40 of our Sun. There was speculation repeated collisions between such massive stars might have led to the formation [...]

item.title: Itokawa Up Close
item.dc:creator: tdumont
item.description:
JAXA released this image of Itokawa’s southern hemisphere. The detail is fantastic and is due to the low altitude of Hayabusa and low solar elevation angles.
Boulders stand out nicely in the image; it is conjectured meteorites are fragments of these asteroids coming into our atmosphere, yet to be proven. Hayabusa is to [...]

item.title: 2 New Moons for “It’s not a planet”?
item.dc:creator: tdumont
item.description: The image above show what very well could be 2 newly discovered moons for Pluto. The images were taken by the Advanced Camera for Surveys on the Hubble Space Telescope between May 15 and May 18. Along with Pluto and Charon, the two potential moons designated P1 and P2 are shown appearing [...]

item.title: Mars
item.dc:creator: tdumont
item.description:
Last night was the night. The closest the planet will be in 13 years at a mere 43 million miles. I wasn’t about to miss out, plus there is a major dust storm underway.
I saw it, sort of. Lots of water vapor and atmospheric instability made Mars all but un-viewable. I [...]
